mods:mods.abstract: Teogonía is a symphonic poem in five sections based on the mural, Teogonía de los dioses chibchas, by Luis Alberto Acuña. Each section introduces one of the Chibcha Gods and the creation story of the Muisca people. Other references that inspired me are symphonic works by Latin-American composers: Silvestre Revueltas, Alberto Ginastera, José Pablo Moncayo, and Arturo Márquez. This work was written in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music from Florida State University. Based on the mural located at the Hotel Tequendama in Bogotá, Colombia, Teogonía is meant to depict the creation story of the Muisca, or Chibcha people. While there are many more characters in the mural, this orchestral work illustrates the five principal Gods of the creation story: Chiminigagua, Súe, Chía, Chibchacum, and Bochica. The piece opens with Chiminigagua, the all-powerful God and creator of the universe. This character is represented by a three-note motive [D-F-G] which is the basis of the piece and reappears in each of the following sections. The piece begins in a primordial state of the universe until the spark of creation which leads into the second section. Súe is the God of the sun and represents light and energy. This upbeat section is characterized by the use of traditional Colombian dance rhythms, most prominently, the bambuco. These rhythms can be identified by the simultaneous and alternating groupings of two and three. The third section depicts the moon Goddess, Chía. In mythology, Chía and Súe are married and perpetually follow each other in the sky. This section is about their love and culminates in the single moment they can be together, during an eclipse. The fourth section tells the story of Chibchacum, God of thunder and rain. The orchestra, here, depicts the great storm that flooded the world, wiping away the corruption that had spread. The final section introduces Bochica who is commonly seen as the messenger of Chiminigagua. Bochica arrives after the great flood on a rainbow and strikes the ground with his staff creating the Tequendama falls. He teaches the Musica people about moral norms, ways to organize their states, agriculture, metalworking, and crafts. This final section concludes the piece and combines statements of all previous Gods' themes.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
Clifton Callender, Professor Directing Treatise; Alexander Jiménez, University Representative; Liliya Ugay, Committee Member; Eren Gümrükçüoğlu, Committee Member.
